text: Kengo Nagashima. Author, maintainer. Hisashi Noma. Author. Toshi . Furukawa. Author.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Nagashima K, Noma H, Furukawa TA. Prediction interval random-effects meta-analysis: confidence distribution approach. Statistical Methods Medical Research 2019; 28(6): 1689-1702. DOI:10.1177/0962280218773520.
code: @Article{,   title = {Prediction interval for random-effects meta-analysis: a confidence distribution approach},   author = {Kengo Nagashima and Hisashi Noma and Toshi A. Furukawa},   journal = {Statistical Methods in Medical Research},   year = {2019},   volume = {28},   number = {6},   page = {1689-1702},   doi = {10.1177/0962280218773520},   note = {Post-print available at (https://arxiv.org/abs/1804.01054)}, }

title: Prediction Intervals for Random-Effects Meta-Analysis
text: implementation prediction intervals random-effects meta-analysis: Higgins JPT, Thompson SG, Spiegelhalter DJ. re-evaluation random-effects meta-analysis. Journal Royal Statistical Society: Series (Statistics Society) 2009; 172(1): 137–159. doi:10.1111/j.1467-985X.2008.00552.x. Partlett C, Riley RD. Random effects meta-analysis: Coverage performance 95% confidence prediction intervals following REML estimation. Statistics Medicine 2017; 36(2): 301–317. doi:10.1002/sim.7140. Nagashima K, Noma H, Furukawa TA. Prediction interval random-effects meta-analysis: confidence distribution approach. Statistical Methods Medical Research 2019; 28(6): 1689–1702. doi:10.1177/0962280218773520. arXiv:1804.01054. Wang C-C, Lee W-C. simple method estimate prediction intervals predictive distributions. Res Syn Meth 2019; 30(28): 3304–3312. doi:10.1002/jrsm.1345. CRAN task view: Meta Analysis

title: Prediction Intervals for Random-Effects Meta-Analysis
code: # From CRAN: install.packages("pimeta")  # Or the the development version from GitHub: # install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("nshi-stat/pimeta")

title: Calculating Confidence Intervals — cima
text: function calculates confidence intervals.

title: Calculating Confidence Intervals — cima
code: cima(   y,   se,   v = NULL,   alpha = 0.05,   method = c("boot", "DL", "HK", "SJ", "KR", "APX", "PL", "BC"),   B = 25000,   parallel = FALSE,   seed = NULL,   maxit1 = 1e+05,   eps = 10^(-10),   lower = 0,   upper = 1000,   maxit2 = 1000,   tol = .Machine$double.eps^0.25,   rnd = NULL,   maxiter = 100 )

title: Calculating Confidence Intervals — cima
text: y effect size estimates vector se within studies standard errors vector v within studies variance estimates vector alpha alpha level prediction interval method calculation method pretiction interval (default = "boot"). boot: parametric bootstrap confidence interval            (Nagashima et al., 2018). DL: Wald-type t-distribution confidence interval            (DerSimonian & Laird estimator \(\tau^2\)            approximate variance estimator average effect,            \((1/\sum{\hat{w}_i})^{-1}\), \(df=K-1\)). HK: Wald-type t-distribution confidence interval            (REML estimator \(\tau^2\)            Hartung (1999)'s varance estimator [Hartung            Knapp (2001)'s estimator] average effect,            \(df=K-1\)). SJ: Wald-type t-distribution confidence interval            (REML estimator \(\tau^2\)            Sidik Jonkman (2006)'s bias coreccted SE estimator            average effect, \(df=K-1\)). KR: Partlett–Riley (2017) confidence interval /            (REML estimator \(\tau^2\)            Kenward Roger (1997)'s approach            average effect, \(df=\nu\)). APX: Wald-type t-distribution confidence interval /            (REML estimator \(\tau^2\)            approximate variance estimator average            effect, \(df=K-1\)). PL: Profile likelihood confidence interval            (Hardy & Thompson, 1996). BC: Profile likelihood confidence interval            Bartlett-type correction (Noma, 2011). B number bootstrap samples parallel number threads used parallel computing, FALSE means single threading seed set value random seed maxit1 maximum number iteration exact distribution function \(Q\) eps desired level accuracy exact distribution function \(Q\) lower lower limit random numbers \(\tau^2\) upper lower upper random numbers \(\tau^2\) maxit2 maximum number iteration numerical inversions tol desired level accuracy numerical inversions rnd vector random numbers exact distribution \(\tau^2\) maxiter maximum number iteration REML estimation

title: Calculating Confidence Intervals — cima
text: K: number studies. muhat: average treatment effect estimate \(\hat{\mu}\). lci, uci: lower upper confidence limits \(\hat{\mu}_l\) \(\hat{\mu}_u\). tau2h: estimate \(\tau^2\). i2h: estimate \(^2\). nuc: degrees freedom confidence interval. vmuhat: variance estimate \(\hat{\mu}\).

title: Calculating Confidence Intervals — cima
text: Excellent reviews heterogeneity variance estimation published (e.g., Veroniki, et al., 2018).

title: Calculating Confidence Intervals — cima
text: Veroniki, . ., Jackson, D., Bender, R., Kuss, O., Langan, D., Higgins, J. P. T., Knapp, G.,  Salanti, J. (2019). Methods calculate uncertainty estimated overall effect size random-effects meta-analysis Res Syn Meth. 10(1): 23-43. https://doi.org/10.1002/jrsm.1319. Nagashima, K., Noma, H., Furukawa, T. . (2019). Prediction intervals random-effects meta-analysis: confidence distribution approach. Stat Methods Med Res. 28(6): 1689-1702. https://doi.org/10.1177/0962280218773520. Higgins, J. P. T, Thompson, S. G., Spiegelhalter, D. J. (2009). re-evaluation random-effects meta-analysis. J R Stat Soc Ser Stat Soc. 172(1): 137-159. https://doi.org/10.1111/j.1467-985X.2008.00552.x Partlett, C, Riley, R. D. (2017). Random effects meta-analysis: Coverage performance 95 confidence prediction intervals following REML estimation. Stat Med. 36(2): 301-317. https://doi.org/10.1002/sim.7140 Hartung, J., Knapp, G. (2001). tests overall treatment effect meta-analysis normally distributed responses. Stat Med. 20(12): 1771-1782. https://doi.org/10.1002/sim.791 Sidik, K., Jonkman, J. N. (2006). Robust variance estimation random effects meta-analysis. Comput Stat Data Anal. 50(12): 3681-3701. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.csda.2005.07.019 Noma H. (2011) Confidence intervals random-effects meta-analysis based Bartlett-type corrections. Stat Med. 30(28): 3304-3312. https://doi.org/10.1002/sim.4350

title: Calculating Confidence Intervals — cima
code: data(sbp, package = "pimeta") set.seed(20161102)  # Nagashima-Noma-Furukawa confidence interval pimeta::cima(sbp$y, sbp$sigmak, seed = 3141592) #>  #> Confidence Interval for Random-Effects Meta-Analysis #>  #> A parametric bootstrap confidence interval #>  Heterogeneity variance: DerSimonian-Laird #>  Variance for average treatment effect: Hartung #>  #> No. of studies: 10 #>  #> Average treatment effect [95% confidence interval]: #>  -0.3341 [-0.5673, -0.0985] #>  d.f.: 9 #>  #> Heterogeneity measure #>  tau-squared: 0.0282 #>  I-squared: 70.5% #>   # A Wald-type t-distribution confidence interval # An approximate variance estimator & DerSimonian-Laird estimator for tau^2 pimeta::cima(sbp$y, sbp$sigmak, method = "DL") #>  #> Confidence Interval for Random-Effects Meta-Analysis #>  #> No. of studies: 10 #>  #> Average treatment effect [95% confidence interval]: #>  -0.3341 [-0.5068, -0.1613] #>  d.f.: 9 #>  #> Heterogeneity measure #>  tau-squared: 0.0282 #>  I-squared: 70.5% #>   # A Wald-type t-distribution confidence interval # The Hartung variance estimator & REML estimator for tau^2 pimeta::cima(sbp$y, sbp$sigmak, method = "HK") #>  #> Confidence Interval for Random-Effects Meta-Analysis #>  #> A Wald-type t-distribution confidence interval #>  Heterogeneity variance: REML #>  Variance for average treatment effect: Hartung-Knapp #>  #> No. of studies: 10 #>  #> Average treatment effect [95% confidence interval]: #>  -0.3287 [-0.5761, -0.0814] #>  d.f.: 9 #>  #> Heterogeneity measure #>  tau-squared: 0.0700 #>  I-squared: 85.5% #>   # A Wald-type t-distribution confidence interval # The Sidik-Jonkman variance estimator & REML estimator for tau^2 pimeta::cima(sbp$y, sbp$sigmak, method = "SJ") #>  #> Confidence Interval for Random-Effects Meta-Analysis #>  #> A Wald-type t-distribution confidence interval #>  Heterogeneity variance: REML #>  Variance for average treatment effect: bias corrected Sidik-Jonkman #>  #> No. of studies: 10 #>  #> Average treatment effect [95% confidence interval]: #>  -0.3287 [-0.5625, -0.0950] #>  d.f.: 9 #>  #> Heterogeneity measure #>  tau-squared: 0.0700 #>  I-squared: 85.5% #>   # A Wald-type t-distribution confidence interval # The Kenward-Roger approach & REML estimator for tau^2 pimeta::cima(sbp$y, sbp$sigmak, method = "KR") #>  #> Confidence Interval for Random-Effects Meta-Analysis #>  #> A Wald-type t-distribution confidence interval #>  Heterogeneity variance: REML #>  Variance for average treatment effect: Kenward-Roger #>  #> No. of studies: 10 #>  #> Average treatment effect [95% confidence interval]: #>  -0.3287 [-0.5815, -0.0759] #>  d.f.: 6.9508 #>  #> Heterogeneity measure #>  tau-squared: 0.0700 #>  I-squared: 85.5% #>   # A Wald-type t-distribution confidence interval # An approximate variance estimator & REML estimator for tau^2 pimeta::cima(sbp$y, sbp$sigmak, method = "APX") #>  #> Confidence Interval for Random-Effects Meta-Analysis #>  #> No. of studies: 10 #>  #> Average treatment effect [95% confidence interval]: #>  -0.3287 [-0.5646, -0.0929] #>  d.f.: 9 #>  #> Heterogeneity measure #>  tau-squared: 0.0700 #>  I-squared: 85.5% #>   # Profile likelihood confidence interval # Maximum likelihood estimators of variance for the average effect & tau^2 pimeta::cima(sbp$y, sbp$sigmak, method = "PL") #>  #> Confidence Interval for Random-Effects Meta-Analysis #>  #> A profile likelihood confidence interval #>  Heterogeneity variance: ML #>  Variance for average treatment effect: ML #>  #> No. of studies: 10 #>  #> Average treatment effect [95% confidence interval]: #>  -0.3301 [-0.5435, -0.1089] #>  #> Heterogeneity measure #>  tau-squared: 0.0547 #>  I-squared: 82.2% #>   # Profile likelihood confidence interval with a Bartlett-type correction # Maximum likelihood estimators of variance for the average effect & tau^2 pimeta::cima(sbp$y, sbp$sigmak, method = "BC") #>  #> Confidence Interval for Random-Effects Meta-Analysis #>  #> A profile likelihood confidence interval with a Bartlett-type correction #>  Heterogeneity variance: ML #>  Variance for average treatment effect: ML #>  #> No. of studies: 10 #>  #> Average treatment effect [95% confidence interval]: #>  -0.3301 [-0.5733, -0.0781] #>  #> Heterogeneity measure #>  tau-squared: 0.0547 #>  I-squared: 82.2% #>

title: Converting binary data — convert_bin
text: Converting binary outcome data effect size estimates within studies standard errors vector

title: Converting binary data — convert_bin
code: convert_bin(m1, n1, m2, n2, type = c("logOR", "logRR", "RD"))

title: Converting binary data — convert_bin
text: m1 vector number successes experimental group n1 vector number patients experimental group m2 vector number successes contorol group n2 vector number patients contorol group type outcome measure binary outcome data (default = "logOR"). logOR: logarithmic odds ratio,                     defined \(=\log \frac{(m1+0.5)(n2-m2+0.5)}{(n1-m1+0.5)(m2+0.5)}\). logRR: logarithmic relative risk,                     defined \(=\log \frac{(m1+0.5)(n2+0.5)}{(n1+0.5)(m2+0.5)}\). RD:    risk difference,                     defined \(=\frac{m1}{n1}-\frac{m2}{n2}\).

title: Converting binary data — convert_bin
text: data.frame study data. y: numeric vector effect size estimates. se: numeric vector within studies standard errors.

title: Converting binary data — convert_bin
text: function implements methods logarithmic odds ratio, logarithmic relative risk, risk difference described Hartung & Knapp (2001).

title: Converting binary data — convert_bin
text: Hartung, J., Knapp, G. (2001). refined method meta-analysis controlled clinical trials binary outcome. Stat Med. 20(24): 3875-3889. https://doi.org/10.1002/sim.1009

title: Converting means and standard deviations — convert_mean
text: n1 vector number observations experimental group m1 vector estimated mean experimental group s1 vector standard deviation experimental group n2 vector number observations experimental group m2 vector estimated mean experimental group s2 vector standard deviation experimental group pooled logical; TRUE, pooled variance used. default FALSE.

Funnel Plot — funnel
text: Function funnel plot `pima` `cima` objects.

title: Funnel Plot — funnel
code: # S3 method for class 'pima' plot(   x,   title = "Funnel plot",   base_size = 16,   base_family = "",   digits = 3,   trans = c("identity", "exp") )

title: Funnel Plot — funnel
text: x `pima` `cima` object plot title graph title base_size base font size base_family base font family digits value digits specifies minimum number significant digits printed values. trans transformation logarithmic scale outcomes ("identity" [default] "exp").

title: Funnel Plot — funnel
code: # \donttest{ data(sbp, package = "pimeta") piex <- pimeta::pima(sbp$y, sbp$sigmak, method = "HTS") cairo_pdf("forestplot.pdf", width = 5, height = 5, family = "Arial") funnel(piex, digits = 2, base_size = 10) #> Error in funnel(piex, digits = 2, base_size = 10): could not find function "funnel" dev.off() #> pdf  #>   2  # }

title: Hypertension data — hyp
text: hypertension data (Wang et al., 2005) included 7 studies comparing treatment effect anti-hypertensive treatment versus control reducing diastolic blood pressure (DBP) patients hypertension. Negative estimates indicate reduction DBP anti-hypertensive treatment group.

code: data(hyp)

title: Hypertension data — hyp
text: data frame 10 rows 2 variables

title: Hypertension data — hyp

title: Pain data — pain
text: pain data (Riley et al., 2011; Hauser et al., 2009) included 22 studies comparing treatment effect antidepressants reducing pain patients fibromyalgia syndrome. treatment effects summarized using standardized mean differences visual analog scale pain antidepressant group control group. Negative estimates indicate reduction pain antidepressant group.

code: data(pain)

text: data frame 22 rows 2 variables

text: y: Standardized mean difference sigmak: Standard error

JAMA. 301(2): 198-209. https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jama/fullarticle/183189 Riley, R. D., Higgins, J. P. T, Deeks, J. J. (2011). Interpretation random effects meta-analyses. BMJ. 342: d549. https://doi.org/10.1136/bmj.d549

title: Calculating Prediction Intervals — pima
text: function can estimate prediction intervals (PIs) follows: parametric bootstrap PI based confidence distribution (Nagashima et al., 2018). parametric bootstrap confidence interval also calculated based sampling method bootstrap PI. Higgins–Thompson–Spiegelhalter (2009) prediction interval. Partlett–Riley (2017) prediction intervals.

title: Calculating Prediction Intervals — pima
code: pima(   y,   se,   v = NULL,   alpha = 0.05,   method = c("boot", "HTS", "HK", "SJ", "KR", "CL", "APX", "WL"),   theta0 = 0,   side = c("lt", "gt"),   B = 25000,   parallel = FALSE,   seed = NULL,   maxit1 = 1e+05,   eps = 10^(-10),   lower = 0,   upper = 1000,   maxit2 = 1000,   tol = .Machine$double.eps^0.25,   rnd = NULL,   maxiter = 100 )

title: Calculating Prediction Intervals — pima
text: y effect size estimates vector se within studies standard error estimates vector v within studies variance estimates vector alpha alpha level prediction interval method calculation method pretiction interval (default = "boot"). boot: parametric bootstrap prediction interval            (Nagashima et al., 2018). HTS: Higgins–Thompson–Spiegelhalter (2009) prediction interval /            (DerSimonian & Laird estimator \(\tau^2\)            approximate variance estimator average effect,            \((1/\sum{\hat{w}_i})^{-1}\), \(df=K-2\)). HK: Partlett–Riley (2017) prediction interval            (REML estimator \(\tau^2\)            Hartung (1999)'s variance estimator [Hartung            Knapp (2001)'s estimator] average effect,            \(df=K-2\)). SJ: Partlett–Riley (2017) prediction interval /            (REML estimator \(\tau^2\)            Sidik Jonkman (2006)'s bias coreccted variance            estimator average effect, \(df=K-2\)). KR: Partlett–Riley (2017) prediction interval /            (REML estimator \(\tau^2\)            Kenward Roger (1997)'s approach            average effect, \(df=\nu-1\)). APX: Partlett–Riley (2017) prediction interval /            (REML estimator \(\tau^2\)            approximate variance estimator average            effect, \(df=K-2\)).            average effect, \(df=\nu-1\)). WL: Wang–Lee (2019) prediction interval /            (method sample quantiles ensemble estimates). theta0 threshold \(\theta_0\), cumulative probability effect \(\theta_{new}\) less greater \(\theta_0\); \(\Pr(\theta_{new} < \theta_0)\) \(\Pr(\theta_{new} > \theta_0)\). side either cumulative probability effect less (default = "lt") greater ("gt") \(\theta_0\) B number bootstrap samples parallel number threads used parallel computing, FALSE means single threading seed set value random seed maxit1 maximum number iteration exact distribution function \(Q\) eps desired level accuracy exact distribution function \(Q\) lower lower limit random numbers \(\tau^2\) upper upper limit random numbers \(\tau^2\) maxit2 maximum number iteration numerical inversions tol desired level accuracy numerical inversions rnd vector random numbers exact distribution \(\tau^2\) maxiter maximum number iteration REML estimation

title: Calculating Prediction Intervals — pima
text: K: number studies. muhat: average treatment effect estimate \(\hat{\mu}\). lci, uci: lower upper confidence limits \(\hat{\mu}_l\) \(\hat{\mu}_u\). lpi, upi: lower upper prediction limits \(\hat{c}_l\) \(\hat{c}_u\). tau2h: estimate \(\tau^2\). i2h: estimate \(^2\). nup: degrees freedom prediction interval. nuc: degrees freedom confidence interval. vmuhat: variance estimate \(\hat{\mu}\).

title: Calculating Prediction Intervals — pima
text: functions bootPI, pima_boot, pima_hts, htsdl, pima_htsreml, htsreml deprecated, integrated pima function.

title: Calculating Prediction Intervals — pima
text: Higgins, J. P. T, Thompson, S. G., Spiegelhalter, D. J. (2009). re-evaluation random-effects meta-analysis. J R Stat Soc Ser Stat Soc. 172(1): 137-159. https://doi.org/10.1111/j.1467-985X.2008.00552.x Partlett, C, Riley, R. D. (2017). Random effects meta-analysis: Coverage performance 95 confidence prediction intervals following REML estimation. Stat Med. 36(2): 301-317. https://doi.org/10.1002/sim.7140 Nagashima, K., Noma, H., Furukawa, T. . (2019). Prediction intervals random-effects meta-analysis: confidence distribution approach. Stat Methods Med Res. 28(6): 1689-1702. https://doi.org/10.1177/0962280218773520. Wang, C-C Lee, W-C. (2019). simple method estimate prediction intervals predictive distributions. Res Syn Meth. 30(28): 3304-3312. https://doi.org/10.1002/jrsm.1345. Hartung, J. (1999). alternative method meta-analysis. Biom J. 41(8): 901-916. https://doi.org/10.1002/(SICI)1521-4036(199912)41:8<901::AID-BIMJ901>3.0.CO;2-W. Hartung, J., Knapp, G. (2001). tests overall treatment effect meta-analysis normally distributed responses. Stat Med. 20(12): 1771-1782. https://doi.org/10.1002/sim.791. Sidik, K., Jonkman, J. N. (2006). Robust variance estimation random effects meta-analysis. Comput Stat Data Anal. 50(12): 3681-3701. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.csda.2005.07.019. Kenward, M. G., Roger, J. H. (1997). Small sample inference fixed effects restricted maximum likelihood. Biometrics. 53(3): 983-997. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/9333350. DerSimonian, R., Laird, N. (1986). Meta-analysis clinical trials. Control Clin Trials. 7(3): 177-188.

title: Calculating Prediction Intervals — pima
code: data(sbp, package = "pimeta")  # Nagashima-Noma-Furukawa prediction interval # is sufficiently accurate when I^2 >= 10% and K >= 3 pimeta::pima(sbp$y, sbp$sigmak, seed = 3141592, parallel = 4) #>  #> Prediction & Confidence Intervals for Random-Effects Meta-Analysis #>  #> A parametric bootstrap prediction and confidence intervals #>  Heterogeneity variance: DerSimonian-Laird #>  Variance for average treatment effect: Hartung (Hartung-Knapp) #>  #> No. of studies: 10 #>  #> Average treatment effect [95% prediction interval]: #>  -0.3341 [-0.8789, 0.2165] #>  d.f.: 9 #>  #> Average treatment effect [95% confidence interval]: #>  -0.3341 [-0.5673, -0.0985] #>  d.f.: 9 #>  #> Heterogeneity measure #>  tau-squared: 0.0282 #>  I-squared:  70.5% #>  #> Estimated cumulative probability of effect `theta_new` #>  Pr(theta_new < 0): 0.9157 #>   # Higgins-Thompson-Spiegelhalter prediction interval and # Partlett-Riley prediction intervals # are accurate when I^2 > 30% and K > 25 pimeta::pima(sbp$y, sbp$sigmak, method = "HTS") #>  #> Prediction & Confidence Intervals for Random-Effects Meta-Analysis #>  #> Higgins-Thompson-Spiegelhalter prediction and confidence intervals #>  Heterogeneity variance: DerSimonian-Laird #>  Variance for average treatment effect: approximate #>  #> No. of studies: 10 #>  #> Average treatment effect [95% prediction interval]: #>  -0.3341 [-0.7598, 0.0917] #>  d.f.: 8 #>  #> Average treatment effect [95% confidence interval]: #>  -0.3341 [-0.5068, -0.1613] #>  d.f.: 9 #>  #> Heterogeneity measure #>  tau-squared: 0.0282 #>  I-squared:  70.5% #>  #> Estimated cumulative probability of effect `theta_new` #>  Pr(theta_new < 0): 0.9460 #>  pimeta::pima(sbp$y, sbp$sigmak, method = "HK") #>  #> Prediction & Confidence Intervals for Random-Effects Meta-Analysis #>  #> Partlett-Riley prediction and confidence intervals #>  Heterogeneity variance: REML #>  Variance for average treatment effect: Hartung (Hartung-Knapp) #>  #> No. of studies: 10 #>  #> Average treatment effect [95% prediction interval]: #>  -0.3287 [-0.9887, 0.3312] #>  d.f.: 8 #>  #> Average treatment effect [95% confidence interval]: #>  -0.3287 [-0.5761, -0.0814] #>  d.f.: 9 #>  #> Heterogeneity measure #>  tau-squared: 0.0700 #>  I-squared:  85.5% #>  #> Estimated cumulative probability of effect `theta_new` #>  Pr(theta_new < 0): 0.8581 #>  pimeta::pima(sbp$y, sbp$sigmak, method = "SJ") #>  #> Prediction & Confidence Intervals for Random-Effects Meta-Analysis #>  #> Partlett-Riley prediction and confidence intervals #>  Heterogeneity variance: REML #>  Variance for average treatment effect: bias corrected Sidik-Jonkman #>  #> No. of studies: 10 #>  #> Average treatment effect [95% prediction interval]: #>  -0.3287 [-0.9835, 0.3261] #>  d.f.: 8 #>  #> Average treatment effect [95% confidence interval]: #>  -0.3287 [-0.5625, -0.0950] #>  d.f.: 9 #>  #> Heterogeneity measure #>  tau-squared: 0.0700 #>  I-squared:  85.5% #>  #> Estimated cumulative probability of effect `theta_new` #>  Pr(theta_new < 0): 0.8598 #>  pimeta::pima(sbp$y, sbp$sigmak, method = "KR") #>  #> Prediction & Confidence Intervals for Random-Effects Meta-Analysis #>  #> Partlett-Riley prediction and confidence intervals #>  Heterogeneity variance: REML #>  Variance for average treatment effect: Kenward-Roger #>  #> No. of studies: 10 #>  #> Average treatment effect [95% prediction interval]: #>  -0.3287 [-1.0280, 0.3706] #>  d.f.: 5.9508 #>  #> Average treatment effect [95% confidence interval]: #>  -0.3287 [-0.5815, -0.0759] #>  d.f.: 6.9508 #>  #> Heterogeneity measure #>  tau-squared: 0.0700 #>  I-squared:  85.5% #>  #> Estimated cumulative probability of effect `theta_new` #>  Pr(theta_new < 0): 0.8534 #>  pimeta::pima(sbp$y, title: Prediction Intervals for Random-Effects Meta-Analysis — pimeta-package
text: Kengo Nagashima, Hisashi Noma, Toshi . Furukawa

title: Plot Results — plot.cima
text: function plotting `cima` objects.

title: Plot Results — plot.cima
code: # S3 method for class 'cima' plot(   x,   y = NULL,   title = "Forest plot",   base_size = 16,   base_family = "",   digits = 3,   studylabel = NULL,   ntick = NULL,   trans = c("identity", "exp"),   ... )

title: Plot Results — plot.cima
text: x `cima` object plot y used title graph title base_size base font size base_family base font family digits value digits specifies minimum number significant digits printed values. studylabel labels study ntick number x-axis ticks trans transformation logarithmic scale outcomes ("identity" [default] "exp"). ... arguments passed methods.

title: Plot Results — plot.cima
code: # \donttest{ data(sbp, package = "pimeta") ciex <- pimeta::cima(sbp$y, sbp$sigmak, method = "DL") cairo_pdf("forestplot.pdf", width = 6, height = 3, family = "Arial") plot(ciex, digits = 2, base_size = 10, studylabel = sbp$label) dev.off() #> pdf  #>   2  # }

text: x `pima` object plot y used title graph title base_size base font size base_family base font family digits value digits specifies minimum number significant digits printed values. studylabel labels study ntick number x-axis ticks trans transformation logarithmic scale outcomes ("identity" [default] "exp"). ... arguments passed methods.

code: # \donttest{ data(sbp, package = "pimeta") piex <- pimeta::pima(sbp$y, sbp$sigmak, method = "HTS") cairo_pdf("forestplot.pdf", width = 6, height = 3, family = "Arial") plot(piex, digits = 2, base_size = 10, studylabel = sbp$label) dev.off() #> pdf  #>   2  # }

what: The Distribution of a Positive Linear Combination of Chiqaure Random Variables — pwchisq
title: The Distribution of a Positive Linear Combination of Chiqaure Random Variables — pwchisq
text: cumulative distribution function distribution positive linear combination \(\chi^2\) random variables weights (\(\lambda_1, \ldots, \lambda_K\)), degrees freedom (\(\nu_1, \ldots, \nu_K\)), non-centrality parameters (\(\delta_1, \ldots, \delta_K\)).

title: The Distribution of a Positive Linear Combination of Chiqaure Random Variables — pwchisq
code: pwchisq(   x,   lambda = 1,   nu = 1,   delta = 0,   mode = 1,   maxit1 = 1e+05,   eps = 10^(-10) )

title: The Distribution of a Positive Linear Combination of Chiqaure Random Variables — pwchisq
text: x numeric; value x > 0 (\(P[X \le x]\)). lambda numeric vector; weights (\(\lambda_1, \ldots, \lambda_K\)). nu integer vector; degrees freedom (\(\nu_1, \ldots, \nu_K\)). delta numeric vector; non-centrality parameters (\(\delta_1, \ldots, \delta_K\)). mode numeric; mode calculation (see Farabrother, 1984) maxit1 integer; maximum number iteration. eps numeric; desired level accuracy.

title: The Distribution of a Positive Linear Combination of Chiqaure Random Variables — pwchisq
text: prob: distribution function.

title: The Distribution of a Positive Linear Combination of Chiqaure Random Variables — pwchisq
text: Farebrother, R. W. (1984). Algorithm 204: distribution positive linear combination \(\chi^2\) random variables. J R Stat Soc Ser C Appl Stat. 33(3): 332–339. https://rss.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.2307/2347721.

title: The Distribution of a Positive Linear Combination of Chiqaure Random Variables — pwchisq
Systolic blood pressure (SBP) data — sbp
text: Riley et al. (2011) analyzed hypothetical meta-analysis. generated data set 10 studies examining antihypertensive drug. Negative estimates suggested reduced blood pressure treatment group.

title: Systolic blood pressure (SBP) data — sbp
code: data(sbp)

title: Systolic blood pressure (SBP) data — sbp
text: data frame 10 rows 2 variables

title: Systolic blood pressure (SBP) data — sbp
text: y: Standardized mean difference sigmak: Standard error label: Labels generated study

title: Systolic blood pressure (SBP) data — sbp
text: Riley, R. D., Higgins, J. P. T, Deeks, J. J. (2011). Interpretation random effects meta-analyses. BMJ. 342: d549. https://doi.org/10.1136/bmj.d549

title: Set-shifting data — setshift
text: Higgins et al. (2009) re-analyzed data (Roberts et al., 2007) included 14 studies evaluating set-shifting ability people eating disorders using prediction interval. Standardized mean differences time taken complete Trail Making Test subjects eating disorders healthy controls collected. Positive estimates indicate impairment set shifting ability people eating disorders.

title: Set-shifting data — setshift
code: data(setshift)

title: Set-shifting data — setshift
text: data frame 14 rows 2 variables

title: Set-shifting data — setshift
text: y: Standardized mean difference sigmak: Standard error

title: Set-shifting data — setshift
text: Roberts, M. E., Tchanturia, K., Stahl, D., Southgate, L., Treasure, J. (2007). systematic review meta-analysis set-shifting ability eating disorders. Psychol Med. 37(8): 1075-1084. https://doi.org/10.1017/S0033291707009877 Higgins, J. P. T, Thompson, S. G., Spiegelhalter, D. J. (2009). re-evaluation random-effects meta-analysis. J R Stat Soc Ser Stat Soc. 172(1): 137-159. https://doi.org/10.1111/j.1467-985X.2008.00552.x

title: Calculating Heterogeneity Variance — tau2h
text: Returns heterogeneity variance estimate confidence interval.

title: Calculating Heterogeneity Variance — tau2h
code: tau2h(   y,   se,   maxiter = 100,   method = c("DL", "VC", "PM", "HM", "HS", "ML", "REML", "AREML", "SJ", "SJ2", "EB",     "BM"),   methodci = c(NA, "ML", "REML"),   alpha = 0.05 )

title: Calculating Heterogeneity Variance — tau2h
text: y effect size estimates vector se within studies standard errors vector maxiter maximum number iterations method calculation method heterogeneity variance (default = "DL"). DL: DerSimonian–Laird estimator (DerSimonian & Laird, 1986). VC: Variance component type estimator (Hedges, 1983). PM: Paule–Mandel estimator (Paule & Mandel, 1982). HM: Hartung–Makambi estimator (Hartung & Makambi, 2003). HS: Hunter–Schmidt estimator (Hunter & Schmidt, 2004).                  estimator negative bias (Viechtbauer, 2005). ML: Maximum likelihood (ML) estimator (e.g., DerSimonian & Laird, 1986). REML: Restricted maximum likelihood (REML) estimator (e.g., DerSimonian & Laird, 1986). AREML: Approximate restricted maximum likelihood estimator (Thompson & Sharp, 1999). SJ: Sidik–Jonkman estimator (Sidik & Jonkman, 2005). SJ2: Sidik–Jonkman improved estimator (Sidik & Jonkman, 2007). EB: Empirical Bayes estimator (Morris, 1983). BM: Bayes modal estimator (Chung, et al., 2013). methodci calculation method confidence interval                 heterogeneity variance (default = NA). NA: confidence interval calculated. ML: Wald confidence interval ML estimator (Biggerstaff & Tweedie, 1997). REML: Wald confidence interval REML estimator (Biggerstaff & Tweedie, 1997). alpha alpha level confidence interval

title: Calculating Heterogeneity Variance — tau2h
text: tau2h: estimate \(\tau^2\). lci, uci: lower upper confidence limits       \(\hat{\tau}^2_l\) \(\hat{\tau}^2_u\).

title: Calculating Heterogeneity Variance — tau2h
text: Excellent reviews heterogeneity variance estimation published (Sidik & Jonkman, 2007; Veroniki, et al., 2016; Langan, et al., 2018).

title: Calculating Heterogeneity Variance — tau2h
text: Sidik, K., Jonkman, J. N. (2007). comparison heterogeneity variance estimators combining results studies. Stat Med. 26(9): 1964-1981. https://doi.org/10.1002/sim.2688. Veroniki, . ., Jackson, D., Viechtbauer, W., Bender, R., Bowden, J., Knapp, G., Kuss, O., Higgins, J. P. T., Langan, D., Salanti, J. (2016). Methods estimate -study variance uncertainty meta-analysis. Res Syn Meth. 7(1): 55-79. https://doi.org/10.1002/jrsm.1164. Langan, D., Higgins, J. P. T., Jackson, D., Bowden, J., Veroniki, . ., Kontopantelis, E., Viechtbauer, W., Simmonds, M. (2018). comparison heterogeneity variance estimators simulated random-effects meta-analyses. Res Syn Meth. press. https://doi.org/10.1002/jrsm.1316. DerSimonian, R., Laird, N. (1986). Meta-analysis clinical trials. Control Clin Trials. 7(3): 177-188. https://doi.org/10.1016/0197-2456(86)90046-2. Hedges, L. V. (1983). random effects model effect sizes. Psychol Bull. 93(2): 388-395. https://doi.org/10.1037/0033-2909.93.2.388. Paule, R. C., Mandel, K. H. (1982). Consensus values weighting factors. J Res Natl Inst Stand Techno. 87(5): 377-385. https://doi.org/10.6028/jres.087.022. Hartung, J., Makambi, K. H. (2003). Reducing number unjustified significant results meta-analysis. Commun Stat Simul Comput. 32(4): 1179-1190. https://doi.org/10.1081/SAC-120023884. Hunter, J. E., Schmidt, F. L. (2004). Methods Meta-Analysis: Correcting Error Bias Research Findings. 2nd edition. Sage Publications, Inc. Viechtbauer, W. (2005). Bias efficiency meta-analytic variance estimators random-effects model. J Educ Behav Stat. 30(3): 261-293. https://doi.org/10.3102/10769986030003261. Thompson, S. G., Sharp, S. J. (1999). Explaining heterogeneity meta-analysis: comparison methods. Stat Med. 18(20): 2693-2708. https://doi.org/10.1002/(SICI)1097-0258(19991030)18:20<2693::AID-SIM235>3.0.CO;2-V. Sidik, K., Jonkman, J. N. (2005). Simple heterogeneity variance estimation meta-analysis. J R Stat Soc Ser C Appl Stat. 54(2): 367-384. https://doi.org/10.1111/j.1467-9876.2005.00489.x. Morris, C. N. (1983). Parametric empirical Bayes inference: theory applications. J Stat Assoc. 78(381): 47-55. https://doi.org/10.1080/01621459.1983.10477920. Chung, Y. L., Rabe-Hesketh, S., Choi, -H. (2013). Avoiding zero -study variance estimates random-effects meta-analysis. Stat Med. 32(23): 4071-4089. https://doi.org/10.1002/sim.5821. Biggerstaff, B. J., Tweedie, R. L. (1997). Incorporating variability estimates heterogeneity random effects model meta-analysis. Stat Med. 16(7): 753-768. https://doi.org/10.1002/(SICI)1097-0258(19970415)16:7<753::AID-SIM494>3.0.CO;2-G.

title: Calculating Heterogeneity Variance — tau2h
code: data(sbp, package = "pimeta") pimeta::tau2h(sbp$y, sbp$sigmak) #>  #> Heterogeneity Variance for Random-Effects Meta-Analysis #>  #> Estimation method(s) #>  Point estimation: Dersimonian-Laird estimator #>  #> No. of studies: 10 #>  #> tau-squared: 0.028 #>
